dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An extravagantly dressed MAN reads to TWO BOYS in a bed.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: ‘Dear little swallow’ said the Prince. You tell me of marvellous things, but more marvellous than this is the suffering of men and women. There is no mystery so great as suffering. Fly over my city, little swallow, and tell me what you see there.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy rain. Blurred dreamlike images appear through it. A group laughing round a table. Feet dashing across wet cobbles. A drenched Child begging by a Morris Column. The black silhouette of a carriage and horses splashing past A street materialises - seen through a sheet of rain pour down the awning of a cafe. People are huddled comfortably inside watching the down pour. MAN V.O. So the swallow flew over the great city, and saw the rich making merry in their beautiful houses, while in the dark lanes, the white faces of starving children looked out listlessly at the black streets. At a table sat a broken man, an empty tumbler by his side with a bunch of withered violets. He was a writer but he was too cold to finish his play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blotchy elephantine vagrant sits alone in a ring of emp tables staring into his glass. He wears a frayed coat and has thin long badly dyed hair. He looks up. Straight at u Dead watery eyes. It is OSCAR WILDE

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: It’s a dream! He drains the glass, rummages for money, rises with difficulty, and shambles off down the crowded street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CITY OF LIGHT in all its glory. Cafes overflow onto t street. 3/11/16  Men and women in evening dress take the air, the ‘monde’ and the ‘demi monde’, urchins selling violets, the whole melting pot are out on this wet October night under the g light, the plane trees and the swirling Van Gogh stars. The rain stops. OSCAR weaves through the crowds with his head down. A BEAUTIFUL WOMAN flanked by TWO MEN in SHINY TOP HATS comes onto the street from a restaurant. They are talking loudly in English. Collision. The WOMAN and OSCAR briefly lock eyes, but he moves quickly on. The TRIO continue, arm in arm. The two MEN chat amiably a the WOMAN looks puzzled. Suddenly

dialogues.speaker: TOP HAT ONE
dialogues.text: What is it, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I think I left my fan. Before TOP HAT can object she has she stops. turned around just in time to see OSCAR disappear in the crowd. She follows, swimming against the lost him. EXT. SIDE STREET. PARIS. NIGHT. In sharp contrast to the brightly alley is dark and empty. OSCAR is the far end. The WOMAN appears at the corner.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Wilde! OSCAR stops. pedestrian tide. She’s lit Boulevard this narrow a lumbering silhouette at With her heart in her mouth the WOMAN moves into the shadows. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: Madam?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Surely you remember me? I am Mrs. Arbuthnott. I came to all your first nights! 3/11/16  FLASHBACK. INT. LONDON THEATRE. NIGHT. 1893. A standing ovation. No sound MRS. ARBUTHNOTT applauds enthusiastically. She is laughin EXT. SIDE STREET. PARIS. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Of course, Madam. One never forgets such a face. How kind of you to speak to me. You are well, I see.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. ARBUTHNOTT
dialogues.text: (moved) I am well, sir, but how are you? The TWO MEN appear at the end of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Lydia. Come here immediately!

dialogues.speaker: MRS ARBUTHNOTT
dialogues.text: I shall have to go.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You couldn't lend me five pounds, could you? Things are a little tight at present. I feel ghastly asking like this, but... MRS ARBUTHNOTT rummages in her purse. Thrusts all her mon into his hand. She is crying.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Lydia!

dialogues.speaker: MRS ARBUTHNOTT
dialogues.text: I’m coming! Goodbye Mr. Wilde. I wish...

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Never wish, Madam. It might come true! But adieu, and thank you for a moments harmony in a discordant fugue. She turns and goes back to the TWO MEN.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Never speak to my wife again or I shall kill you, do you hear? 3/11/16  10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TWO MEN laugh and applaud. No sound. EXT./INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. PARIS. NIGHT. 9 OSCAR enters the hotel d’Alsace. He climbs the stairs of this dark and dingy HOTEL. Sounds of a squabble as a door opens and shuts. He drags himself up by the banister. He stops to catch hi breath. He holds his ear as if there is a deafening noise M. DUPOIRIER, the HOTEL manager is coming down the stairs with a TRAY.

dialogues.speaker: DUPOIRIER
dialogues.text: (in french) Any news of your bank draft, today, M. Melmoth?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (also in French) Alas no, M. Dupoirier, but fear not, M. Ross is arriving tomorrow with royalties, contracts and cash.

dialogues.speaker: DUPOIRIER
dialogues.text: Excellent news, Monsieur! INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. BEDROOM. NIGHT. 10 Lit by a flickering gas jet. OSCAR’S room is small with a linoleum floor and dark wallpaper featuring tightly packe flowers and leaves. A small window looks out onto a courtyard. OSCAR regards himself in a MIRROR. His ear is bleeding. H touches it carefully with a finger, then smears the mirro with blood.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: See! See where Christ’s blood streams through the firmament! His reflection shimmers and the room suddenly lurches behind him. OSCAR blinks and clutches the table.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is happening to me? 3/11/16  11 12 The strange spasm passes and he applies rouge and foundation. Greases his hair with an evil looking tinctur sprays some perfume in his mouth and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG MAN and a BOY sit at a back table - JEAN a handsome twenty year old who sells violets, and his consumptive brother LEON, a matchstick boy. Although they are rough, LEON is weeping. JEAN sees OSCAR and gestures.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (french) What is the matter with our little sparkler. Dear Leon weep no more. I beg!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: The sisters from the Orphanage came for him, and all his matches got nicked.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: (bursting into fresh tears) Don’t let them take me back there Jo. I'll be more careful, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is it could be better for everyone. You'll be safe and I wont always be worrying. It’s getting too fucking dangerous around here.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: But we’re brothers. We should be together. LEON puts his head in his hands and cries. JEAN sighs and looks at OSCAR for help.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Well, this is too frightful! But I too have news. A sudden windfall enables me to offer you both at least absinthe and cocaine on the eve of departure and a purple moment for me, if, Leon, you will lend me your relation for the usual consideration? 3/11/16  13 He produces a coin. LEON looks up. Takes the coin.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: (sniffing) Well... twenty minutes. And you have to finish that story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR lies on a filthy bed in a squalid room. Noises of bonking and bedsprings through the ceiling. JEAN, a lithe panther with his trousers down, sprinkles powder into cotton wool balls, puts one in the side of his mouth and gives another to OSCAR.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You know I don’t think I’ve ever been happier in my life. In this room. At this moment. The light from the street.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What light?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: It carves you in marble, dear boy! We are lost in our own world. Shrouded in a symphony of adjacent copulation. It’s really quite good! He counts out notes on the bed. JEAN looks at him with obvious affection.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you love me, Johnny, even though our purple hours are sullied by green notes. But what can one do? OSCAR lurches from the bed, doing up his flies, tucking i his shirt, to the door. He opens it. LEON falls in.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: (unapologetic) That was nearly an hour. Story time.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Where was I?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Under the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Under the bridge. 3/11/16  14 15 They all pile onto the bed. LEON coughs.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Under the bridge two little boys were lying in one another’s arms to try and keep themselves warm. How hungry we are they said. You must not lie here shouted the watchman and they wandered out into the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incongruous TRIO walk down a rainy street. OSCAR V.O. The swallow flew back and told the prince what he had seen. I am covered with fine gold said the prince. You must take it off leaf by leaf and give it to the poor; the living always think that gold can make them happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. MEN in TALL HATS, TARTS and PIMPS. Banquettes overflow. WAITERS weave through the tables with loaded trays. A stringy WOMAN sings on a stage at one end of the hall. She is dressed for a beggars ball and harshly lit by footlights. OSCAR and THE BROTHERS arrive. OSCAR surges towards the stage, interrupting the performance.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Dear Lottie, sing to me sweet nightingale and crack my calcified heart with your warbles. Garcon! They settle at a table. A WAITER appears

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Absinthe. A YOUNG MAN in uniform, MAURICE GILBERT is talking with another man in the shadows

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahh, mon legionnaire! Maurice, come here immediately and ravish me! 3/11/16  MAURICE prowls across the room towards OSCAR who watches him transfixed. LEON and JEAN giggle helplessly. MAURICE salutes and OSCAR pulls him on to his knee. A MAN with a TART watches them in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Revolting pig! Returning to your vomit! MAURICE grabs the man by his lapel, still sitting on OSCAR'S knee. The TART shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: You insult my friend, Monsieur. Apologize now or I will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me, filth. MAURICE leaps up sending the table flying. Glasses smash. Wine is spilt. THE TART screams again.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (oblivious ) How could I resist. Look! The profile of Napoleon... MAURICE shakes the MAN like a rat. A chair breaks. They fall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: without any of the more disappointing features!

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE
dialogues.text: You don’t speak to my friend like that, understand. Cunt! Standstill. Music stops. WAITERS surge forward led by THE MANAGER, a stocky woman in black.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Him, out! Take your tart with you! You, soldier. Sit down

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Ahh, Madame, a few ruffled plumes, no more

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: You! Shut your fucking face. Look at the damage! Who’s paying? 3/11/16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. I shall sing for you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Shut up, Oscar. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (wide eyed) May I? THE MANAGER turns to the room.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: What do you say? Sing or pay?

dialogues.speaker: SING
dialogues.text: LOTTIE the stringy singer shields her eyes and squints through the footlights.

dialogues.speaker: LOTTIE
dialogues.text: What the fuck’s going on? THE BOYS pick up the table and haul OSCAR onto it. A shak follow spot crosses the hall, picking out sweaty faces, glassy eyes and open mouths till it circles OSCAR, pantin and livid. MAURICE starts a round of applause. Whistles and cheers. THE BAND plays an introduction.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: The boy I love is up in the gallery. The boy I love is looking down at me. There he is! Can’t you see? Waving his handkerchief. As merry as a cricket that sings on the lee THE CROWD enjoy the show and sing along with the chorus, the delight of OSCAR and his friends. Tremendous applause as the song ends. OSCAR is bleeding from the ear. His eyes bulge and he is sweating. Hair dye and powder trickle down his ecstatic face. He swoops down into an elaborate bow and crashes unconscious to the floor. A huge burst of applause. 3/11/16  16 17 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR (back to us) straightens from a deep bow. He is before a glittering first night audience. The theatre is packed.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: The actors have given us a charming rendering of a delightful play. More applause. CONSTANCE, OSCAR’S wife watches nervously. GROUP OF YOUNG MEN, ROBBIE ROSS, REGGIE TURNER, and other wear green carnations.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And your appreciation has been most intelligent. Faces explode with mirth. Details of glistening teeth. Ferocious eyes. Manic applause. Whispering in ears. MRS ARBUTHNOTT sits between the TWO MEN laughing. OSCAR looks like a toad in the footlights and throws a hu shadow against the red velvet curtain behind him. He has metallic blue carnation in his buttonhole and a gold tipp cigarette smoking in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I congratulate you on the success of your performance... Hysterical laughter. which persuades me that you think almost as highly of the play as I do myself. OSCAR waits for the next laugh, but there is none, only a uncomfortable silence with a few coughs. CONSTANCE covers her face with her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another audience, grim and menacing. Another stage. The dock. A HAMMER knocks three times.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Oscar Wilde the crime of which you have been convicted is so bad... 3/11/16  18 19 20 11 OSCAR watches horrified. THE MARQUIS OF QUEENSBURY stares at him intently from the front row of the court. JUDGE V.O. that one has to put a stern restraint upon oneself from describing the sentiments which must rise to the breast of every man of honour who has heard the details of these two terrible trials. ROBBIE ROSS bows deeply as OSCAR is hustled through the crowd. PROSTITUTES dance on the street. NEWS VENDORS shout.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is no use to address you. THE MARQUESS OF QUEENSBURY is mobbed on the steps of the court. JUDGE V.O. (CONT’D) People who can do these things must be dead to all sense of shame. I shall under such circumstances be expected to pass the severest sentence that the law allows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR'S head is shaved. JUDGE V.O. It is, in my opinion, totally inadequate for such a case as this. A naked OSCAR is plunged into a brackish bath. JUDGE V.O. (CONT’D) The sentence of the court is that you be imprisoned and kept to hard labour for two years. 3/11/16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the sound of mayhem in court, OSCAR, in prison uniform is thrown into a cell. As the door slams and locks the ro cuts out. An eye looks through a tiny spy hole in the door. Through the hole OSCAR sits on a board in the small brick room with his head in his hands. M. DUPOIRIER V.O. Monsieur Melmoth. Monsieur Melmoth. Your friend is here. OSCAR looks up at the door. The eye disappears. INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. OSCAR’S BEDROOM. DAY. 1900 22 OSCAR opens his eyes. He is in bed. He sighs with relief. It was a dream. His ear is bandaged. M DUPOIRIER is standing over him. DR. TUCKER, from the British Embassy, prepares an injection From OSCAR'S point of view M. DUPOIRIER flares and sparkles. The wallpaper pulses with OSCAR’S heartbeat. ROBBIE ROSS leans over the bed. He wears a travelling coa OSCAR is hallucinating.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (weakly) Robbie! My lonely rider of the apocalypse. You took me into exile, dear boy. Where will you take me now. What ship? Ireland, you say? ROBBIE sits on the edge of the bed and takes OSCAR’S hand

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No ships, Oscar. I am here in Paris. I have your allowance.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Ah, good. Good. I have been dinnerless. OSCAR stares at the wall. The flowers shimmer and jump. H groans.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am in mortal combat with this wallpaper, Robbie. One of us has to go! 3/11/16  23 13

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Maurice says you made quite a scene last night.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: It is more or less impossible to make good scenes in such reduced circumstances as mine, but I believe I did my best. Last night I dreamt I was supping with the dead.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You must have been the life and soul of the party, Oscar. DR. TUCKER rolls up OSCAR’S sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Morphia is mere seltzer to me now, but good Dr. Tucker will only give me ether or chloral on holidays of obligation. I am much distracted dear boy. I have had a very bad time lately, and for two days not a penny in my pocket, so had to wander about, filled with wild longings, trapped in the circle of the boulevards, one of the worst in the inferno. The needle goes in. OSCAR visibly relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I shall never forget your kindness, dear boy, when I was released from prison. What high hopes we had that day! But I was doomed from the start. Why does one run towards ruin? Why does it hold such a fascination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A green misty sky merges with the sea. ROBBIE ROSS stands on the quay looking out to sea. The noise of a horn bounces across the sleepy port and ou the mist the NEWHAVEN PACKET SHIP materializes. Smoke fro the funnel curves across the sky. ROBBIE catches sight of the boat and runs down the jetty. On board the ship a lone OSCAR watches the harbour approach. 3/11/16  24 25 26 14 When he sees his friend he throws back his head and laugh The ship docks. OSCAR lumbers down the gangplank. The men embrace warmly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar, How are you?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Where is Reggie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: He’s waiting for us at the Hotel. He wanted to make sure there were no...

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Difficulties. Have you got everything?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: No. I left Oscar Wilde at Newhaven. He gives ROBBIE a folder that he has clasped to his chest

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this is the last thing she wrote. The great letter I told you about. Make three copies. Send one to Bosie Douglas. One to me, and keep the original under lock and key. OSCAR relaxes, as though a heavy weight is lifted from hi shoulders. The TWO MEN climb onto the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and ROBBIE drive through the town towards the hotel climb down from the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and ROBBIE enter. 3/11/16  27 15

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (suddenly tense) If anyone asks you for documents or papers, just say they are in your cabin trunk. Before OSCAR has time to reply

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, well, well! If it isn’t Sebastian Melmoth. Dear boy, what an absolute joy. REGGIE TURNER, a portly Brigadier with a handsome moustac leaps from a chair. He hugs OSCAR and then takes him by t arm, leading him towards the reception counter.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this your first time in Dieppe, Sebastian? What fun! Let me introduce you immediately to our dear friend the Manager. Ring, ring, ring bangs REGGIE on the desk. THE HOTEL MANAGER arrives with a servile smile.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Melmoth, this is M Duroc. Look after Mr. Melmoth, would you? The best room, and all that. I'’11 leave you to it, Are you lunching? Before OSCAR can answer REGGIE leaves. THE MANAGER proffers the registration book for OSCAR to sign.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Shall we take your valuables, your papers, Sir, and keep them in our safe?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: They are in my cabin trunk. OSCAR signs with a flourish and a sideways glance. A mome as the MANAGER scrutinizes the signature and beams.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Monsieur Melmoth. Bienvenue en France INT. HOTEL SANDWICH. OSCAR’S SUITE. DAY. 27 In the sitting room are flowers, books, a smart set of ne luggage monogrammed with S.M. 3/11/16  16 A dressing case filled with glass vials. There are new clothes and a pile of letters. OSCAR gasps with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: The cases are from Reggie. And here is eight hundred pounds we raised while you were in prison. It will keep you going until you begin to work again. REGGIE comes into the room. The three men explode with laughter and hug.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Darling Oscar! How do you like your new name?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: As much as I loathe the old one. Ah, letters! REGGIE produces a framed picture of QUEEN VICTORIA from t new dressing case while OSCAR leafs through his mail.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: And look! No exiled fairy’s toilet is complete without a signed portrait of the great Widow herself. You must dance naked before it during the jubilee next month.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (suddenly tense) -+. It’s from him!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar...

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I may as well tell you both now that I fully intend to affect a reconciliation with my wife - if she will have me. And rest assured that I shall never see Lord Alfred Douglas again. That part of my life is behind me.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, he’s in Paris, and determined to see you.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: As I am determined NOT to see him. OSCAR tears up a letter ostentatiously and throws it in t hearth. 3/11/16  28 29 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAITERS push a fleet of trolleys. A burst of laughter from inside OSCAR’S rooms. INT. HOTEL SANDWICH. OSCAR’S SUITE. DAY. 29 THE THREE MEN are sitting around a table in a haze of cigarette smoke. WAITERS clear plates and pour coffee.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: From what you say, Oscar, it would seem that Reading Gaol is an enchanted castle with the Governor as its presiding elf.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Robbie! I met Christ in prison.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What was she in for?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Don’t joke Reggie. In the cell there is only God and Man. After three days in hell Jesus rose from the dead. Discarded his cerements, broke open the tomb and took his place forever in the heart of man. After seven hundred days of hard labour my tomb has opened, I have tiptoed to the boat train and I am born again. Through him with him and in France.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Very good Oscar. We’ll make a Catholic of you yet!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Only unlike dear Jesus you have luggage and eight hundred pounds to spend before your ascension into heaven.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Or purgatory. I’m afraid a delegation of fifteen young poets is arriving from Paris at the weekend to welcome you into exile. They are bringing a cheque. 3/11/16  30 31 18

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Oh Good. All I am saying, dear Reggie, is that I lived in the grip of vice and pleasure. It was wrong and I have paid. Perhaps the slate is wiped clean. Perhaps it is not. We shall see. At any rate I am ready to return to life. INT. HOTEL SANDWICH. OSCAR’S SUITE. DAY. 30 Alone, OSCAR unpacks. Framed pictures of CONSTANCE and HI CHILDREN are extracted from an open cabin trunk. He retrieves BOSIE’S shredded letter from the fireplace, sit at the desk and tries to reassemble it.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: (screaming) I hear from your so called friends that you no longer wish to see me! Can it be that you have forgotten all you said before you went to prison? Nothing but my love sustained you then, your soul clung to my soul. Now you no longer wish to know me. God knows I have suffered too during these two years. There is prison without prison, but I will tell you this. Never, for one moment has the intensity of my love for you faltered. I feel as I felt the day I met you. I have waited for this day for two years. I am now half crazed with grief. When this letter reaches you I might be dead! OSCAR laughs bitterly and sweeps the torn pages off the desk and starts a letter of his own. Seagulls fade into the noise of children playing. INT. CONSTANCE’S HOUSE HEIDELBERG. DAY. 31 A THIN HUNCHED WOMAN in a neck brace opens a letter. It i CONSTANCE, OSCAR'S wife. Outside in the garden TWO CHILDR play. OSCAR V.O. Constance my dear good beautiful wife, there is nothing I can ever say that will undo the great hurt that I have caused you. We both know that. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two years have I lain on hard boards, knelt on cold stone, dined on shame and thought of little else. OSCAR V.O. (CONT’D) You and my sons are the only things that tie me to life. Were it not for the hope that one day I would meet you all again, I don’t think I could go on. CONSTANCE looks sadly at her children playing in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR, REGGIE, ROBBIE are served a sumptuous lunch. A PRETTY WAITER bends over the table. OSCAR’S eyes briefl alight on his apron wrapped posterior. After the boy has gone everybody laughs. OSCAR is slightly indignant. OSCAR V.O. My desire to live, dearest Constance, is as intense as ever, and though my heart is broken, hearts are made to be broken. OSCAR gestures grandly for more champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With OSCAR’S gesture the room changes to night. Candles flicker on tables. Guests in evening dress. The champagne arrives at another meal. This time a dinner with FIFTEEN YOUNG POETS and STUDENTS who have come from Paris to welcome OSCAR into exile. They are eccentrically dressed and extremely rowdy. OSCAR captivates the table with tales of prison. Other guests watch sternly. The party bays for a speech from OSCAR, banging the table. OSCAR V.O. That is why God sends sorrow to the world. Write to me as soon as you can and tell me that I am still your Oscar. OSCAR stands to make a toast. 3/11/16  34 35 20

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: That the delicate buds of French art should find their way to this desert outpost in order to welcome and raise this bruised and trodden lily from the slough of despond fills it with the tremulous hope that it could still live and bloom again on the double peak of Parnassus... The WAITER brings the bill.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, did I ask for that?

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOTEL SANDWICH BEACH. DAY. 34
dialogues.text: OSCAR - a tiny dot - leaves the Hotel and walks across a stretch of empty beach to a solitary chair. A GROUP OF ENGLISH STUDENTS play makeshift cricket far off. He sits watches. A ball lands nearby and a lithe boy in a bathing suit runs up to fetch it. Looks at OSCAR.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Bonjour.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Bonjour. THE BOY runs back to the group. He tells them something. They look round towards OSCAR and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR nibbles a croissant alone at a table, enjoying the bustle on the quay. The rowdy group of CRICKETERS amble along the street and install themselves at the next table. OSCAR appraises them covertly. They see OSCAR and begin to whisper and giggle. OSCAR stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH ONE
dialogues.text: Not wearing your lovely silk stockings today Oscar? The CRICKETERS explode with mirth. OSCAR stares resolutely ahead. 3/11/16  36 21 ENGLISH ONE (CONT’D) Darling boy?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH TWO
dialogues.text: Yes, my hyacinth?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH ONE
dialogues.text: Remind me to change the sheets today darling boy. Your slim gilt cheeks have left a shit stain all the way down your side of the bed! Hysteria. OSCAR stands.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You go too far, Sir! ENGLISH ONE stands.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH ONE
dialogues.text: No! You went too far. Madam. HE beckons to a WAITER ENGLISH ONE (CONT’D) Garcon, there’s a lump of shit on the pavement. Get rid of it! A dangerous moment. REGGIE and ROBBIE appear a little way off, take one look and storm across the street towards th cafe.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Ah there you are, Oscar. We’re late. They’re waiting for us. He takes a frozen OSCAR by the arm and leads him away before the situation has time to escalate. ROBBIE follows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THREE MEN walk fast

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (weakly) No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Lets go back to the Hotel THE ENGLISH MEN appear around the corner whooping and laughing. 3/11/16  37 38 22

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Christ! They’re following us!

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH ONE
dialogues.text: Wait for me! I want to cover you in honey and lick it off again.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: This is intolerable OSCAR, REGGIE and ROBBIE quicken their pace. The chase is on. They duck down an alleyway. THE UNDERGRADUATES stampede round the corner, baying and yelping like hounds. They are intensely amused. One has picked up a branch and is banging it against dust bins an doorways. OSCAR ROBBIE and REGGIE are running now. Across a graveyard. Through a gate. THE UNDERGRADUATES are getting closer. Jumping over the graveyard wall, laughing and shrieking. OSCAR, REGGIE and ROBBIE turn into a lane. It is a dead end. Sweating and panting, they are literally up against the wall. THE UNDERGRADUATES surge around the corner. There is no escape.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK. CLAPHAM JUNCTION STATION PLATFORM. DAY 1895. 3
dialogues.text: A CROWD OF ANGRY TRAVELLERS shout and jeer. A BURLY MAN j his finger at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something clicks inside OSCAR’S head and with a roar he lunges at the first man, throwing him to the ground with his enormous weight. He bounces up, rage and adrenalin pounding through his veins, and hurls a second against th wall, his huge hands around the MANS throat.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (shouting) What more do you want? THE UNDERGRADUATES are stunned. OSCAR throws the second M aside like a twig. He is hysterical now, a stampeding elephant. 3/11/16  23

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have taken everything, you little shits. Everything! My family. My home. My work. My freedom. Everything. There is nothing else to take. OSCAR shoves a RUDDY CHEEKED BOOR in the chest. He backs off

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Kill me? I’m already dead, you cunt. Now piss off all of you. The natural habitat of the hypocrite is England. Get back there! Leave me in peace. GO. THE YOUNG MEN’ stand uncertainly for a moment then turn around and shuffle off. By the time they get to the corne they have recovered their swaggers and slap one another o the back as they run off. Their whoops of victory sound like mad bird cries echoing through the village. It begins to rain. The THREE FRIENDS look at one another for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you had it in you.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I don’t. I have nothing in me, not even fear.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK. EXT. CLAPHAM JUNCTION PLATFORM. DAY. 1895 3
dialogues.text: A TRAIN noisily speeds through the station revealing OSCA with a shaved head, sitting on a bench. He is manacled to PRISON WARDEN. OSCAR V.O. With no warning, I was transferred one afternoon from Wandsworth to Reading Gaol. In broad daylight, by train, shackled to a warder like a performing bear, that journey was the most exquisite of the tortures Her Majesty contrived for me. 40 INT. HOTEL SANDWICH. OSCAR’S SUITE. NIGHT. 1897 40 OSCAR is in bed. REGGIE and ROBBIE sit either side.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: At Clapham Junction we had to wait for a connection. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Half and hour, my dears, on platform three. Sadly my public had not forgotten me. 4l FLASHBACK. EXT. CLAPHAM JUNCTION. DAY. 1895 41 A small crowd begins to gather. A BURLY TROUBLEMAKER begi to lecture the crowd. OSCAR V.O. At first they simply giggled and pointed, but then a man began to shout. He paced up and down, wagging his finger, as he catalogued my crimes to his growing and spellbound audience. Now the crowd is huge. The platform is packed. Several hundred people pressing against the bench where OSCAR sit THE BURLY MAN is purple now. In slow motion he inhales an spits a huge gob which lands on OSCAR’S face. The CROWD applauds. 42 INT. HOTEL SANDWICH. OSCAR’S SUITE. NIGHT. 1897. 42

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: At each new twist the crowd moaned and swayed as one, spitting and screaming, howling for my blood.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK. EXT. CLAPHAM JUNCTION STATION PLATFORM. DAY
dialogues.text: THE WARDEN reads the evening paper with rapt attention as OSCAR is rained with spittle OSCAR V.O. While I? I saw the future. It was the end of all peace. 44 INT. HOTEL SANDWICH. OSCAR’S SUITE. NIGHT. 1897. 44

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (simply) I shall see it on my death bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE and REGGIE are in the hall. THE MANAGER stiffly gives them a letter.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Please give this to M WILDE. 3/11/16  46 47 48

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh dear! Its from the Chief of Police. You read it. ROBBIE opens it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It seems he is to be deported if his behavior does not improve. Our celebration of young french poets didn’t go down very well in the voisinage.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, don’t show him now, for God’s sake! In his current mood he could set fire to the Hotel! Thank Christ I’m leaving tomorrow. The go upstairs, arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You be careful, Robbie. He’1l eat you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and ROBBIE leave the hotel. Their luggage follows, carried by BELLBOYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HOTEL stands above the dunes. The beach stretches awa in both directions. The sea crashes and a flock of seagul wheel over the water diving for fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE and OSCAR climb from a carriage and go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager leads Oscar and Robbie to their room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and ROBBIE at a table in front of a large window overlooking the sea. They are finishing a meal. There is full moon. 3/11/16  26

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I read your letter from prison. It is really rather marvellous. You should call it De Profundis.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Well it was written from the depths!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Bosie will probably try to kill you when he reads it.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I wrote some harsh letters to you Robbie. I am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You wrote harsh letters to us all. We were trying our best.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I know. Its hard to describe the feeling of utter impotence and desperation in there. One becomes a fury. One never speaks. One simply weeps and has diarrhea. Result: lunacy. Do you forgive me? OSCAR takes ROBBIE’S hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Who would have thought, that afternoon we met, fifteen years ago, that here we’d be. Lepers dining under a full moon ina foreign hotel. It’s quite romantic in a way.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Except that you, dear boy, are not a leper. Tomorrow you will blow away on the sea breeze - destination Dover - like a dandelion seed. As to who would have thought? We met in a public lavatory, Bobbie dear, and we ended up here. You wouldn’t have to be the Sybil of Mortimer Street to join the dots!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I was going to a matinee! 3/11/16  50 27

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: And I was going to my club. A different corner, a minute later, another play, and maybe I should be the poet laureate, but I doubt it. Intimacy in the sewers followed by fantasy in the Gods! The rest is silence. FLASHBACK. INT. PUBLIC LAVATORY. LONDON. AFTERNOON. 1886. A quiet afternoon in the echoing underworld. Cisterns dri ROBBIE (younger) stands at a long line of urinals. OSCAR breezes in, takes a place further along the line. ROBBIE moves next to OSCAR. Surprised, OSCAR looks up. Eyes meet. ROBBIE leaves the urinal, and casually goes into a cubicl OSCAR buttons up and nervously follows. THE QUEENY LOO ATTENDANT raises a pair of plucked eyebrow and continues to read his paper. Inside the cubicle a trembling OSCAR fills the whole spac ROBBIE is squashed against the toilet. Neither one can un their trousers. From a hole in the wooden partition a tongue waggles. OSCAR suppresses a little shriek. ROBBIE smiles and puts his finger to his lips as he tries to undo OSCAR’S flies.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Got a place? OSCAR looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Meet you outside. He leaves. OSCAR, alone, is undecided. THE TONGUE waggles and speaks

dialogues.speaker: TONGUE
dialogues.text: Go on dear, risk it fora biscuit. OSCAR ostentatiously flushes the loo, and leaves. 3/11/16  51 52 53 54 28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE waits under a street light in the smoggy dusk. OSCAR lumbers up the steps from the underworld and joins him, and they walk off into the fog together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A transfigured OSCAR holds a sleeping ROBBIE in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distracted OSCAR smokes in bed while ROBBIE sleeps besi him. INT. BEDROOM. HOTEL D’ALSACE. NIGHT. 1900 54 ROBBIE sleeps in a chair. OSCAR, clearly ill, watches him from the bed by the light of a low fire.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Bobbie! Bobbie. ROBBIE wakes suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dear boy, help me to the commode, would you? ROBBIE hauls OSCAR from his bed and heaves him onto the commode. The two men look at one another. OSCAR is now stripped of all dignity

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have observed a very curious thing. Just when one thinks there is no further to go, there is ... further to go. Have I let you down, terribly, darling Bobbie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (moved) Of course not Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You had such plans for me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I wanted you to be happy. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Happiness is cheep perfume that even I couldn’t afford. 3/11/16  55 56 57 29

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I just.. wanted you to write. You made the world happy with your writing.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Some of it. But you never understood. There was nothing left. Just one spark, then black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR walks across the dunes towards a small BATHING HUT the sand. He unlocks the door and goes in. A minute later he comes out in a bathing costume and marches into the sea, finally crashing in like a porpoise He swims back and forth without his hair getting wet. Waves splash in his face. OSCAR V.O. He did not wear his scarlet coat, For blood and wine are red, And blood and wine were on his hands When they found him with the dead,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR sits back from his desk smiling.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: The poor dead woman whom he loved, and murdered in her bed! Superb. He continues writing. INT. CONSTANCE’S HOUSE HEIDELBERG. DAY. 57 TWO GRAVE VICTORIAN MEN sit with CONSTANCE. Through an op window THE CHILDREN can be seen playing.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOWARD
dialogues.text: As the boys guardian I cannot impress upon you too strongly my alarm at your being in contact with your husband at all! Be extremely cautious, Madam, when you reply to his letter. He passes her some papers to sign. 3/11/16  58 30

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Holland.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wilde!

dialogues.speaker: MR HOWARD
dialogues.text: Constance. We have been friends for many years. I am the executor of your grandfathers estate. You must trust us. Please sign. The children are fighting in the garden. She gets up. She can hardly walk, practically bent double on two sticks.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Cyril! Vivian! Stop fighting! She shuts the window. Sudden silence. The children fight behind her in a dumb show. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) My trouble is that once I have made up my mind to love someone, I can never change. EXT. CONSTANCE’S HOUSE HEIDELBERG. DAY 58 CYRIL and VIVIAN listen by the door to the conversation inside. CONSTANCE V.O. I feel sure that if I saw him once, I should forgive him everything. MR. HOWARD V.O. Precisely, my dear, and then you would be stuck here in Heidelberg forever. Heidelberg! CONSTANCE V.O. We like it. MR HOWARD V.O. You must wait! Think of your children. He must prove to you that he will change. That he can. You have time. Don’t hurry. CONSTANCE V.O. Very well I will do as you both suggest. I will harden my heart for the sake of the boys. 3/11/16  59 60 61 31 INT. CONSTANCE’S SITTING ROOM. DAY. 59 CONSTANCE sits down and begins to write a letter. She loo out of the window. THE CHILDREN are now sitting quietly under a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE and OSCAR walk on the sand.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Since you left I have been completely alone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar, that’s simply not true!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: My wife has written me a revolting letter in which she tells me that PERHAPS she will see me at some later date, but not in the foreseeable future, and the boys probably never!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: But Oscar I am amazed that you should imagine that Constance would want to see you at all! You write her one letter full of your usual perfumed shit and you suppose that everything you've put her through for the last few years can simply be forgotten!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Robbie, if you have come here to upset me, I suggest you return to Dieppe immediately where you will find a train that leaves at three minutes past the hour. Every hour!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I am not here to upset you Oscar! I just want you to be reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Bosie, whom you all deplore, at least offers to help me. 3/11/16  32

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh really? How, Oscar? How is Bosie going to help you?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Bosie loves me Robbie. In a way that you could never understand. In any case he’s is coming here next week.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Then you will never see Constance again. You seem to forget that despite everything you have put her through she still allows you four pounds a week. That four pounds, Oscar, is dependant upon Bosie’s absence from your life. But doubtless he will settle some money upon you when he gets here. If his mother has given him any!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (screaming) I am all alone. I don’t have anyone. Why are you being so harsh

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You have me, Oscar! I am here! No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it’s not enough, is it? Why is it not enough, Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Well frankly my dear you’re not really grand enough and you're certainly not rough enough. Lets get a drink for Gods sake. OSCAR takes ROBBIE’S arm and they walk back towards the HOTEL in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't be cross, Bobbie! You weren’t built for rage. I went on the most marvellous pilgrimage yesterday to Notre Dame de Liesse. Did you know that liesse is the medieval word for happiness? I go there every day. 3/11/16  62 63 64 33

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. COUNTRYSIDE AND NOTRE DAME DE LIESSE. DAY. 62
dialogues.text: OSCAR walks through some fields towards a small chapel on hill. He is slightly breathless. OSCAR V.O. It takes all of three minutes to get to it and just as many to get back. The Priest, who is charming, has become a great friend. Yesterday he showed me all his vestments. He looked particularly captivating in his martyr's garb - rose doree streaked with blood. OSCAR goes in and sits alone in the chapel. AN OLD BENT PRIEST comes in and shuffles towards the alte drops with difficulty to his knees, grasps the foot of a particularly gruesome crucifix and kisses the feet of Jes OSCAR is transported and for a moment CHRIST seems alive. gazes at OSCAR with great compassion. OSCAR V.O. (CONT’D) You see Robbie, suffering is nothing when there is love! Love is everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR lost in thought. Grubby windows streaked with rain. Low clouds. Thunder. The rhythmic clanking of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breathless OSCAR climbs on the vast clanking machine OSCAR V.O. Dear Bosie, After long and fruitless waiting I have determined to write to you myself, as much for your sake as for mine, as I would not like to think that I had passed through two long years of imprisonment without ever having received a single line from you, or any news or message even, except such as gave me pain. 3/11/16  65 66 67 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR reads through a stack of papers.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Our ill fated and most lamentable friendship has ended in ruin and public infamy for me, yet the memory of our ancient affection is often with me, and the thought that loathing, bitterness and contempt should forever take that place in my heart once held by love is very sad to me.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR V.O.
dialogues.text: You came to me to learn the pleasure of life and the pleasure of art. Perhaps I am chosen to teach you something much more wonderful, the meaning of sorrow and its beauty. The sun comes through the clouds. The train arrives in ROUEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TRAIN pulls away from the station. Through the clouds of smoke OSCAR is revealed standing on the platform. In the distance BOSIE is still a golden youth in a dusty travelling coat. He slowly walks towards a frozen OSCAR. Finally, the two men face each other. Close up BOSIE is ravaged and pinched. OSCAR begins to cry. Tries to speak but can’t.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oh come on Oscar! It’s not like you to have nothing to say. OSCAR heaves.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oscar! BOSIE takes OSCAR in his arms and hugs him. They go to a bench. Sit side by side. OSCAR is still prostrate. BOSIE holds his hand. 3/11/16  68 69 35

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: Is he alright.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: He’s had some bad news! OSCAR looks up. Smiles. The two men begin to laugh and cr A Train passes. From the other side of the platform. Now they are really laughing. Talking. Gesticulating Another train. Through the stream of passengers OSCAR and BOSIE are silent, sitting side by side. The platform is deserted again. A guard lights gas lamps the day fades.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Bosie, about that letter I sent you from prison...

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: I never got it! What did it say?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Nothing important now. It was just my testament. De Profundus.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oh Oscar, you silly old fairy, come here! BOSIE takes OSCAR in his arms and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I am my own Judas. I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few people dine. OSCAR and BOSIE sit at a table drinking. TRAVELLERS come and go.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: What are your plans? 3/11/16  36

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What plans can I have? The doom of Melmoth is to wander the earth seeking shelter where he can. I may go south.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Naples. See it and die!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: If only it were that simple! A GOODS TRAIN clanks through the station.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Have you written anything?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: A ballad about prison. Its almost finished. Rather good. I don’t know if I can write anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Why? Now more than ever you must write.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I wrote when I knew nothing of life. Now that I do know it there is nothing left to write.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oscar, lets run away! Somewhere no one could find us. Naples in fact.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Dear boy, you don’t know what you are saying. I’m starving. Do let's order. Times passes. Later...

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do we huddle without the city walls at a Station Hotel? A MAN walks through the dining room announcing a night train to Belgium.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because I am a ruined man. If you came with me to Naples the world would become a picture you could look at but never touch. Do you love me that much, Bosie? And anyway, we have no money! 3/11/16  70 71 72 73 37

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, money! Oscar, for Christ’s sake. My mother has got masses. What are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Nothing. Something Robbie said.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Robbie has been against me ever since we met. He is riddled with jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: He loves me, Bosie, in a way that you could never understand. Shall we take a room? Sudden tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR sits on the bed. BOSIE stands before him in his shirt. He begins to remove OSCAR turns out the light. In the darkness lights flash across the wall as a train thunders through the station. bloodcurdling scream of its whistle accompanies OSCAR and BOSIE as they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Train with OSCAR and BOSIE aboard speeds through long tunnel. The scream continues. Their faces are barely visible in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train thunders through the tunnel towards a dot of li The scream intensifies. INT. ROBBIE ROSS’ HOUSE LONDON. DAY. 73 ROBBIE reads a letter. The noise of the train and its scream continues.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: My going back to Bosie was psychologically inevitable. I cannot live without the atmosphere of love; I must love and be loved, whatever price I pay for it 3/11/16  74 75 76 77 38 ROBBIE puts down the letter and cries.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TUNNEL . DAY 74
dialogues.text: The train explodes from the tunnel into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bay of Naples is covered in an early morning mist. Th scene is ravishing. OSCAR stands on the terrace of his new home Villa Guidice in Posilippo. OSCAR V.O. I dare say what I have done is fatal. I love him as I always did. With a sense of tragedy and ruin.. The trains whistle turns into a high pitched human shriek

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOSIE stands on a chair in his underwear screaming as a huge rat darts back and forth across the room. THREE seed Neapolitan servants are trying to kill it with brooms and bats - CARMINE, a fat bearded lady cook, her husband PEPPINO and their son MICHELE. MICHELE finally skewers it with a rake. It writhes about while the PEPPINO clubs it death and its brains splash across the floor. OSCAR rushe in. Everyone is shouting. BOSIE is hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oscar! Another rat. There are fucking rats everywhere! MICHELE picks the animal up by the tail and waves it victoriously. This is the last straw for BOSIE who leaves the room cursing.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: We need La Corridone.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: The witch. Rats very afraid of her. INT. CONSTANCE’S HOUSE. HEIDELBERG. DAY 77 Another scream. This one is strangled from CONSTANCE. 3/11/16  39

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I forbid it! I forbid him to live with that infernal man.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: There was nothing anyone could do.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I shall not pay him his allowance. You may tell him as much when you see him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That is unlikely Madam. I have resigned as his literary executor. CONSTANCE regards ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t know you are here, I presume?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, Madam he does not.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Why do you mind so much. ROBBIE doesn’t reply. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) They all tell me to be wary of you, Mr Ross. They say you can’t be trusted. But we are the same, you and I. He has hurt you as well, hasn’t he? ROBBIE cannot answer. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Oscar destroyed himself and everyone around him. Look at me, Mr Ross. Just look at me! She looks deranged for a second. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) He has killed me. And yet, I still love him. Strange, isn’t it? She shivers. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Someone must be walking on my grave. 3/11/16  78 79 40

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. VILLA GUIDICE. DAY. 78
dialogues.text: AN ANCIENT GYPSY WOMAN walks slowly around the house singing and waving burning twigs. THE STAFF are terrified and hold rosaries. OSCAR watches from the terrace. THE WITCH comes into the garden and sees OSCAR. OSCAR offers her cash. There is a deep rumbling noise. They look up. A cloud ris from MOUNT VESUVIUS. THE WITCH looks at him for a long moment and shakes her head, refusing his money. She turns away. Walks through the house and out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remains of a long and alcoholic dinner are strewn across the table in front of them. Bottles of liqueurs. A band plays and a lady sings. AN EXTREMELY ATTRACTIVE WAITER serves a spellbound BOSIE. MOTHER, the proprietor of the restaurant observes happily

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: The good news is there are no more rats. The bad news is that my allowance has been cut off.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Do you always have to talk about money during dinner?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Obviously I should much prefer to discuss serving techniques with our waiter but we must make some sort of plan, Bosie. I came here at your invitation. You said you had funds. You do not. I accept that. But the fact remains we now have, what, six pounds.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Five. I had to pay last weeks renter. BOSIE winks at the WAITER as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Careful! His mother is watching. 3/11/16  41

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Yes, and she’s thrilled! Don’t be a bore Oscar! What has happened to you? OSCAR doesn’t rise. BOSIE watches the WAITER intently.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have six pounds a week from my mother. We still have a hundred pounds for the libretto you will never write. We still have studs and cufflinks, friends and relations. And above all we still have each other. One of us could eat the other and make a tent out of the hide. For Gods sake stop worrying. OSCAR remains silent. BOSIE beckons to the WAITER, who rushes over to the table with a bottle of wine which he uncorks.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Italian) What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Felice.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: This is Signor Melmoth. I am Alfred. I have seen you at the beach. You have a strong chest and shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: FELICE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Si. He fills their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You always talk to boys as though they were bloodstock, Bosie. You should ask them to lift their hoofs and show their mouths..

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: And then thrash’em. I need to make sure they don’t fall at the first fence. THE WAITER leaves. BOSIE follows him. OSCAR is left alone 3/11/16  80 81 82 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a crack in a door CARMINE and PEPPINO watch entranced and horrified as OSCAR, holding a whip and dressed as Phedra recites Racine. FELICE stands uncertain in the middle of the room while BOSIE is bound and gagged tied naked to a chair. The crack of a riding crop against naked flesh. PEPPINO winces. OSCAR V.O. Come on, dear, Fuck him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mattress on the floor under a ripped mosquito net. The debri of last nights party on the floor. BOSIE and FELICE sleep tangled up in the dirty sheets. OSCAR watches from chair. Noise of sea crashing and seagulls screaming. He g up and quietly leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge red sun rises over the bay. A pink cloud sits on t of Vesuvius. A fishing boat moves slowly towards Capri. Fishermen dive from its prow. Their voices come and go on the breeze. OSCAR watches. BOSIE appears wrapped in a sheet. Sits on the wall. Light cigarette, hands it to OSCAR. They smoke in silence.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (finally) Its very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: You see?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: I can make you happy!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Yes. You can. No more anxiety, no more ambition. No time. Just now. Boys diving for pearls, an old sheep with his butcher, a bobbing boat on a silver sea, and scandal, just a small black dot against the edge of dawn. 3/11/16  83 84 43

dialogues.speaker: EXT COUNTRY HOUSE ENGLAND. DAY. 83
dialogues.text: ROBBIE walks to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY QUEENSBURY sits erect in widows black in a large beautiful room. A BUTLER enters, followed by ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Mr Ross, m’lady.

dialogues.speaker: LADY QUEENSBURY
dialogues.text: Thank you Paine. How do you do, Mr. Ross? Sit down won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lady Queensbury.

dialogues.speaker: LADY QUEENSBURY
dialogues.text: I will come straight to the point. I gather my son is living with your friend in Naples. I’m reliably informed that you may be able to help me. I must rescue Lord Alfred from the clutches of Mr Wilde.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Or Mr Wilde from the influence of your son, Lady Queensbury. I was under the impression that you and Mr Wilde were friends.

dialogues.speaker: LADY QUEENSBURY
dialogues.text: Indeed? Hardly. I was revolted by him on sight. An oily indolent toad dazzled by society. I said nothing of course - a mother knows when to keep quiet -— although my flesh crawled when he entered a room. The connection with my son made him giddy. Drunk. Lord Alfred was only twenty.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with the circumstances of their early friendship? The reason Lord Alfred approached Mr Wilde in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: LADY QUEENSBURY
dialogues.text: Not exactly, no. 3/11/16  44

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Then I shall tell you. Your son was being blackmailed by a young man at Oxford. Bosie asked Mr Wilde to help him. Oscar did. A Lawyer was found. Money was paid - by Wilde - never repaid. The problem was resolved and put on a ship bound for Australia. Later on, it was your son who introduced Oscar to the alleys and lanes of Whitechapel, and the nighttime markets of living flesh. Just as it was your son who was guilty of all but one of the crimes for which Mr Wilde was later convicted. Nevertheless, Lady Queensbury we should stand united. Together we may be able to separate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARMINE, PEPPINO and their SON pilfer silently across the room, moving through moonbeams while BOSIE and OSCAR snor bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR has been cooking. BOSIE is dangerously drunk.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what a cunt you look in that apron. Suddenly I'm fucking your mother.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Sit. Are you fucking me?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Yes you are. I can hear you.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: (imitating OSCAR) All middle aged poofs end up like their mothers. That is their tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Look, Bosie. It is not my fault we have been pillaged by our own servants. Try to be civil, or at any rate misquote me accurately. 3/11/16  45

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: What is this anyway?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Pomodoro e aglio al forno. It is all Mother Hubbard has left in her cupboard. The postal order from your brother Percy has still not arrived. I have been down to the post office three times already this morning.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: God, I’m sick of all this. Always waiting around for a hand out. They eat in silence.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you ever noticed how people look around before they can even see us. At first I couldn't understand why. And then one day I saw a man sniffing as he turned. They can smell you coming my dear. Its quite a feat. The stench of raw scandal is quite overpowering. OSCAR is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to say anything. I’m just sick of it, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Well maybe you should just pack up and get out. Go back to your mother.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: How could I? They would say that I'd abandoned you. Again. Robbie, Reggie, the whole Greek chorus.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I could help you out. I was thinking of going to the beach this afternoon but, on reflection perhaps it would be more convenient if I simply adjourned to some overflowing Neapolitan latrine and blew my brains out! 3/11/16  86 46

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Possible!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You would learn of the tragedy at tea time on the beach from one of your favourite sailors, and by supper time you would be in deep mourning on all fours and the day would be yours. With him till the end. Thick and thin. Sickness and health you semi literate jumped up little shit. BOSIE throws the contents of his plate at OSCAR. A tomato lands on his face. A moments stunned silence. BOSIE laughs. There is a knock on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MANS VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello! Is there anyone at home. OSCAR and BOSIE look at one another in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, a visitor. Is someone finally leaving a card. Lay the tray for Tea, Oscar, there’s a pet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOSIE sits with a rather stiff English Diplomat, BEAUCHAM DENIS BROWN.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: What brings you to Naples, Beauchamp.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUCHAMP
dialogues.text: Various things. I don’t know whether you are au courant but the Prime Minister is building a house nearby. The Ambassador wanted me to take a look. Make sure everything is ship shape. Had a few days to myself and thought I’d look you up.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: How kind. I would offer you some tea but unfortunately the servants seem to have fled during the night. 3/11/16  47

dialogues.speaker: BEAUCHAMP
dialogues.text: It couldn’t matter less old boy. Aren’t they absolutely hopeless here? How is your dear Ma?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: She is on splendid form. We spent a month together in Baden Baden. Now she is back in England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR listens from the shadows. BEAUCHAMP V.O. Bosie, I wanted to have a quiet word, if I may? BOSIE V.O. By all means. BEAUCHAMP V.O. The Ambassador feels that your living here in broad daylight with er ... BOSIE V.O. Oscar. BEAUCHAMP V.O. Yes, precisely. Living here with Mr Wilde is very, shall we say, awkward. Mal vu, you understand. Sir John has such fond memories of your long sojourn at the Embassy and wants very much to avoid any ... how shall I put it....embarrassment, particularly with the PM in such close quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR comes into the garden with a tea tray still wearing his apron. BEAUCHAMP looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Ah, Oscar. Do you know Beauchamp Brown. We were at school together. BEAUCHAMP stands. Refuses OSCAR’S hand.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUCHAMP
dialogues.text: How do you do. 3/11/16  89 90 48

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Beauchamp says that our living here together is a scandal. OSCAR. My whole existence is a scandal. Tea, Mr. Brown?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUCHAMP
dialogues.text: Thank you, no. Well I must be pressing on. Do think about our little chat, won’t you Bosie and come and see us in Rome when you are passing through. BOSIE takes him into the house. OSCAR stares out to sea. The front door slams. BOSIE walks slowly towards OSCAR. Puts his arms around hi and leans his head on OSCAR’S shoulder. Closes his eyes. They are silent for a moment. Noise of sea etc.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You're right. It is a bore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR is writing at a table under a tree. BOSIE is composing a sonnet. Crickets buzz. Boiling noon. FELICE, half naked, is raking the gravel. OSCAR puts down his pen. Gathers up the papers. Looks out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: It is finished!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse pulls a cart up the steep volcano. BOSIE and OSCA climb down and continue on foot. They are bickering.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR V/O
dialogues.text: All men kill the thing they love. By all let this be heard. Some do it with a bitter look. Some with a flattering word. 3/11/16  91 92 93 94 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and BOSIE are shown round this vast mausoleum carve into the rocks by a GUIDE with a flaming torch. PEOPLE pr in front of alters made entirely of skulls.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR.V/O
dialogues.text: The coward does it with a kiss The brave man with a sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and BOSIE walk down into the city, through thin dar streets festooned with washing. They are not talking.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: They hanged him as a beast is hanged. They did not even toll a requiem that might have brought rest to his startled soul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and BOSIE deep in conversation. A YOUNG MAN passes. They both look up. OSCAR V.O. But hurriedly they took him out, And hid him in a hole. The Chaplain would not kneel to pray

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another table. BOSIE and OSCAR, dressed in warm clothes a laughing. It is Christmas time. TWO YOUNG MEN pass. One, good looking, turns back. OSCAR V.O. By his dishonored grave; Nor mark it with that blessed cross, That Christ for sinners gave, Because the man was one of those Whom Christ came down to save. Later. THE TWO YOUNG MEN sit with BOSIE and OSCAR. BOSIE deep in conversation with the good looking one. OSCAR mak valiant headway with the UGLY FRIEND. 3/11/16  95 96 97 98 99 50 INT. CONSTANCE’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 95 CYRIL, VIVIAN and CONSTANCE are looking at their Christma tree.

dialogues.speaker: CYRIL
dialogues.text: Is father all alone in the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Of course not, darling. At Christmas all the patients have a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what a party. BOSIE and the usual FISHERMEN and SAILO are playing strip musical chairs in front of a large tree lit by candles. OSCAR plays a piano. They wear paper hats and little else. The music stops and everyone runs for a chair. INT. CONSTANCE’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 97 CONSTANCE and her children hold hands and sing a carol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayhem. A candle falls off the Christmas tree. The music starts again. The group run around the chairs wide eyed and sweaty. A branch catches fire. The music stops and a fight breaks out between TWO FISHERMEN. OSCAR comes in to break it up. Suddenly the whole Christmas tree is engulfed by flames. INT CONSTANCE’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 99 The noise of flames becomes the rustling of paper. CYRIL unwraps a present from OSCAR, a ship in a bottle. VIVIAN hides behind a curtain.

dialogues.speaker: CYRIL
dialogues.text: But this is an Italian ship. VIVIAN runs to his mother. CYRIL rolls his eyes. 3/11/16  100 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke. Screams. A bucket of water is thrown. Most of it lands on OSCAR A LOCAL WOMAN bursts through the door. She is accompanied by a shy GIRL of 18 clutching a wailing baby in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Where is my son?

dialogues.speaker: FELICE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? THE LOCAL WOMAN lunges at FELICE. Slaps him hard. THE YOU WIFE watches in horror. The BABY screams.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Shame on you. Look at her! Your wife! How can you insult us like this. I know what you are doing here.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: And what might that be, Madam?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Where are the harlots, the loose women who are leading my son to hell? Show them to me. I will drag them onto the street by the hair. Afterwards my husband will castrate you S. Melmoth.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: But, Signora. There are no women here.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: This is a gentlemen’s party.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Liar! THE WOMEN stalks around the room, oblivious to the fact that almost everyone is half naked. She opens doors. Everyone waits in silence. The YOUNG WIFE watches anxiously. The BABY whimpers. Finally the WOMAN comes bac into the room, laughs, goes over to her son and kisses hi on the head WOMAN (CONT’D) Oh bimbo, scusa me! Signor Melmoth, I am sorry. I thought there were women here. But I see I was wrong. Bless you Signor. We will leave you. 3/11/16  101 102 She slaps her son hard over the head, takes by the arm. WOMAN (CONT’D) Don’t make a noise when you come in, cicio. She leaves. The company burst out laughing, dances around the burnt Christmas tree. INT. CONSTANCE’S HOUSE. NIGHT. CYRIL is trying to remove the ship from the been given.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Vivian. This one is from Papa.

dialogues.speaker: CYRIL
dialogues.text: Vivian doesn’t know who Papa is.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Yes I do. 52 the YOUNG WIFE and the party 101 bottle he has CYRIL looks at his present for a moment, and then smashes on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VILLA GUIDICE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: 102 BOSIE, deeply drunk, in his underwear has been cornered b FELICE who is holding a broken bottle to his throat.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What on earth is going on?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: One can run up a bill for everything in this swamp except sex it seems.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: There is never credit where love is concerned, Bosie. You should know that. Felice, Caro, believe me he isn’t worth it. Shall I take that? OSCAR takes the bottle from FELICE’S hand, away. BOSIE starts to speak.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be silent! Now, what does he owe you?

dialogues.speaker: FELICE
dialogues.text: My honour, signor. and leads him 3/11/16  53

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: What bollocks!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I said be quiet. We are rather strapped for cash at present but this should see you through until tomorrow. OSCAR gives FELICE a silver framed photograph of CONSTANC and the TWO BOYS

dialogues.speaker: FELICE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Signor Melmoth. You gentleman, but this! This is pig.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Well spotted. So clever of you to notice!

dialogues.speaker: FELICE
dialogues.text: He does not know the value of anything.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Nor the price, unfortunately. Now lets find your coat. Your wife will be getting worried. OSCAR ushers him out of the room. BOSIE, pulling up his trousers, loses his balance and crashes to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: What the hell did you give him that for? OSCAR comes back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: A foolish question, I know, but why didn’t you just pay him?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: With money. Silence. BOSIE staggers to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: I haven’t got any.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you haven’t got any? Silence. 3/11/16  54

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: My mother has stopped my allowance.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What? When did this happen? Oh Christ!

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: I was waiting for the right moment to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: But in the mean time you imagined that wretched boy would fuck you for fun.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: And why not?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Your vanity is extraordinary. The only person who ever fucked you for fun was me! And look where it got me. The dock! So that’s it then. We appear to have come to the end of the road. We’re penniless.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Well, not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: You could have two hundred pounds and I could keep my allowance.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: If?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Well, what Mama and the family really can’t stomach is the fact that we live together. She says that if we agree to separate she will reinstate my allowance and, very generously, I think, give you this substantial....

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Tip! For services rendered. To the Family. Would I get a good reference? Can I keep my cottage? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God, you all make me sick. Your sanctimonious mother thinks that I can be brought off for two hundred pounds. Your family has destroyed me, stripped me of everything, not least my genius. And all for two hundred pounds!

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Genius! You destroyed yourself, Oscar, because underneath the pose there was NO SUBSTANCE. One good comedy, three pot boiling melodramas and those ridiculous fairy stories. That’s all you find if you scrape away the powder and the pancake. Your success was interesting. Your hunger for it perversely fascinating. But you, my dear, never were!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You found me interesting enough when you were faced with blackmail.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: You were in your element. You saw the green baize door swing open and you scuttled through it.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You are talking drivel. My father...

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Was a drunken groper with dirty fingernails just like his son.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Whereas YOUR father is an assassin at large!

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Oscar, you’re still alive.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Barely. OSCAR collapses to a chair gasping for breath and clutchi his heart.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: For God's sake, stop acting. OSCAR looks up at BOSIE 3/11/16  103 104 56

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: It’s strange. I’ve never really looked at you before. I gave you my whole life and now I see it before me daubed in shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PORTER loads BOSIE’S luggage on to the train. BOSIE lea out of the window. OSCAR stands gloomily on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: I'll write to you when I get to Rome. Where will you be?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I've really no idea. I suppose I may as well stay here until the lease runs out. Then I shall probably go to Paris. Who knows? At any rate we’ll be in touch. Dear boy, do you mind awfully if I don’t wait? I’m not really made for waving pocket handkerchiefs at parting trains. He turns and lumbers away down the platform waving as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm too big! BOSIE watches OSCAR disappear into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR wakes. The furniture is rattling and the room is bathed in a weird glow. Through the window Vesuvius is erupting. Lava spews from the crater. OSCAR watches entranced. The door opens and CONSTANCE appears.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Hello Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Constance? Is it...

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Where is Lord Alfred? Has he left? Are you quite alone now?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Where are the boys? 3/11/16  105 106 107 57

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I must get on. Such a long way to go. She rises, bent double and walks towards the wall.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
