dialogues.text: Constance, we never meant to ...

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I loved you so much. Always. Odd, isn’t it... CONSTANCE disappears. A disembodied GIRLS VOICE sings.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: The boy I love is up in the gallery The boy I love is looking down at me There he is, can’t you see, waving his handkerchief... VIOLENT KNOCKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR wakes and stumbles to the front door. An URCHIN hands OSCAR a telegram. INSERT TELEGRAM: Regret to inform you Constance dead. Genoa. Internment private. Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handcart is being loaded with OSCAR'S battered luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR looks out to sea. He turns around and walks through the bedroom. He takes the photograph of QUEEN VICTORIA fr the bedside table. He walks through the house with it, dropping the keys on the floor as he goes through the fro door. Without looking back he follows the handcart. 3/11/16  108 109 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR sits vacantly looking through the window of a third class carriage ploughing through the night. CONSTANCE V.O. Will you be coming home soon? The boys miss you terribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONSTANCE stands in the long hotel corridor. She has a pi of letters. OSCAR stands inside the door. He is not letti her in. Behind him a grandiose room can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: If only I could remember the address! BOSIE appears in a djellabha.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: What address? Are you leaving me Oscar? How are you Constance?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Bosie. Quite well. Oscar, We shall be at home this afternoon. Do try!

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, nursery tea! What fun. We’1ll both come, won’t we Oscar. OSCAR shuts the door. That was a narrow escape. A STOCKY youth stretches in the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONSTANCE presides at the table. OSCAR and BOSIE either side smoking and laughing at a private joke. The TWO LITT BOYS watch silently.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I am nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowflakes flutter from a heavy white sky past the large windows of a cafe. 3/11/16  59 OSCAR sits at a table in a shabby overcoat, lost in thought. A YOUNG MAN, (JEAN) comes into the bar with a wicker bask half full of bunches of snowdrops. He is ragged and froze

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: A bunch of flowers sir. Two for a centime. OSCAR wakes from his reverie and gazes at the YOUNG MAN.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Ah! Snowdrops. The frozen tears of God. I’1l have them all. What is your name, dear boy?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Jean, sir

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Jean, sit with me. Have a drink to warm you up.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (looking around) Not here, Sir. But you can buy me one later at the Calisaya if you fancy.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I certainly do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and JEAN are drinking absinthe.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I used to be quite famous, you know. JEAN rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes! When was that?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You don’t believe me but it’s true. OSCAR momentarily loses his train of thought.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was so famous that once I was even lowered down a mine in a bucket. 3/11/16  114 60

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: The dear miners had invited me to dinner. JEAN is uneasy. OSCAR laughs. Two more glasses arrive on the table. OSCAR puts one arm around JEAN. With the other he pours water onto sugar cubes in the two glasses of Absinthe. He is a deft seducer.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed. I traveled the length and breadth of the Americas. My own train. The interior, upholstered in green morocco. Your very good health! They clink glasses and drink. OSCAR’S fleshy bejeweled ha begins to crawl along JEAN’S leg. His face moves in close his voice is melodious and intimate. JEAN is mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I civilised America. It took quite a long time, but I think it was worth it. In the rocky mountains is a town called Leadville. I spoke to the young miners of Leadville on the need for beauty. OSCAR'S hand has arrived at JEAN’S crotch and squeezes. H eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You're mad!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. Quite mad. Now, ona more serious subject where did you steal those two jewels.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What jewels?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Your eyes!

dialogues.speaker: INT HOVEL, CLIGNANCOURT. DAY. 114
dialogues.text: Black screen. A CHILDS VOICE counts. OSCAR wakes on a mattress that is more like a dog basket a hut with a mud floor. 3/11/16  61 A THIRTEEN YEAR OLD BOY (LEON) is counting matches into match boxes in the corner of this shanty dwelling. OSCAR doesn’t know where he is. Groans. THE BOY jumps up

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: (screaming) He’s awake. JEAN, the YOUNG MAN from last night, appears.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Where am I? And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Clignacourt. I’m Jean. And this is Leon. JEAN nudges LEON towards OSCAR. The boy holds out his han gingerly. OSCAR shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Extremely glad to know you, Monsieur

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Give me some money. JEAN slaps LEON over the head.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Oi! Behave.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: And I‘'1l cook him an egg!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: How kind. Now where is my pocket book? To his surprise, he finds it in his breast pocket. Gives note to LEON who dashes from the house. JEAN watches as OSCAR rises with difficulty from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm afraid last night is rather a blur. I like your brother. JEAN starts to make up a fire in a makeshift grate.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He shouldn't be here. Haven’t seen him in five years. Then one day he just turns up. All the way from Lille. 3/11/16  62 OSCAR looks around. Rough plank walls. Tarpaulin roof. Di floor. A photograph is pinned to the wall of a woman.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Ah! Family. So important. Is that your mother.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Was. JEAN goes outside.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (looking at the picture) I have two sons. JEAN comes back in with wood.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’ve got quite a head. Later, LEON cooks eggs in a saucepan over a small fire at the side of the room. The BROTHERS eat, ravenously. OSCAR watches.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (deeply touched) Shall I tell you a story? I am rather good at stories.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (mouth full) Another time, Monsieur. We have to work. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and the TWO BOYS walk through the snowy lanes of th Parisian favela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow turns to rain. A summer downpour. The street glitter and steams. The terrace is packed. OSCAR, penniless, sits at a table and nurses the remains of a drink. Later, he is talking to an ENGLISH VICAR and HIS FRIEND, holding forth, as the bill arrives. OSCAR beams as they p and leave. Later he is alone looking at the rain. WAITERS watch him from inside the bar. 3/11/16  63 Suddenly the awning in front of the bar is cranked back, huge deluge of water falls on OSCAR. The WAITERS laugh. A very drunk OSCAR sits in the pouring rain. His hat is drenched. People stare as they go past and he waves pathetically. ROBBIE ROSS walks by. OSCAR sees him

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Robbie! Stop a moment. Please! ROBBIE turns back. He is under an umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar! Why are you sitting in the rain?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I have spent all my ready cash on youth and beauty, and I cannot pay. Do help me Robbie. Please ROBBIE is shocked by OSCAR’S state

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Lets go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE and OSCAR sit. OSCAR, exceedingly drunk, calls the WAITER.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Like dear St. Francis, I am wedded to poverty. Only in my case, the marriage is not a success. Robbie, you are naughty. How long have you been here? (to waiter) How much do we owe you?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Twelve francs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes) Twelve francs? God, Oscar!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Its been a long day. Do you have twelve francs or not, dear?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Of course (to the waiter) Thank you. 3/11/16  64

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Once again I am in your debt. (to waiter) Absinthe. Two. Bobbie I have missed you so much. Months of punitive silence. Naples was, as you so accurately predicted, a disaster. ROBBIE smiles despite himself.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It seems as though I am always asking for it, but do I have your forgiveness?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Forgiveness is for amateurs, and you, dear Oscar, are a professional masochist. Come on, I’1l take you home

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Oh, dear boy so cruel!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Anyway, to be pardoned would mean nothing to you. You always want to serve the full sentence. Can you forgive yourself?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Oh, Robbie, what an uncompromising curtain raiser. The ruined woman hardly knows how to react. Should I leave the room, or should I fall again into your arms? Of course Bobbie, you silly little thing I shall never forgive myself for being born! 118 EXT. STREETS AND HOTEL D’ALSACE. NIGHT. 118 OSCAR and ROBBIE walk back to the Hotel. ROBBIE has to support OSCAR who stumbles and weaves.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: To think that I have wasted so much time, sacrificed everything, for a person who was quite simply not my style. However. Now I have a young panther who quite twists my lips with kisses...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Spare me the details! 3/11/16  65

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: With a little brother of thirteen who enjoys my stories. They live together at Clignacourt The little one has the consumption and sells matches. You shall meet them. They are quite charming.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Indeed. But the poets. The artists. Your old friends. What of them?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Lost in the mist, dear boy. I am a vampire. I lurk in the noon shadows, blanched by sunlight, but at dusk I bloom, a deadly nightshade that kills with a kiss. Sometimes they see me. The old friends. Leaving a cafe. Under a lamp. Getting off the omnibus, and I see them, their faces twisted with terror and disgust, as though the gates of hell suddenly gaped before them. It’s really quite amusing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: But you have not lost everything, Oscar. Reading Gaol is the most successful poem ever written

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Most successful. Most brilliant. Most promising. Most ambitious. Most cruel. Most sorrowful. Most dangerous. Most disgusting. Words! Words! Words are irrelevant. Do you think I’m going mad?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, Oscar, but I don’t believe a ‘word’ you say.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: No. I am going mad. I shall never write again, Bobbie. I don’t need to. A life of squalor has been revealed to me. I embrace it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar. You do not live in squalor. There is light and water... 3/11/16  66

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: And linoleum and indescribable wallpaper. But let us not squabble like two disgruntled housemaids. Let us rather black our grates with a light heart and chatter about our betters. Bosie, we hear, has come into twenty thousand pounds. He arrives next week. I thought I might touch him for a tiny pour boire when I dine with him. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, he has brought a stud outside Paris.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Typical. He knows absolutely nothing about horses and yet he always manages to back the loser. (suddenly coy) Will you come up, Robbie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, Oscar. Lets forget all that. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Did I hurt you terribly? THE TWO MEN look at each other. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I think you hurt yourself more. Good night, Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Then until tomorrow. We shall have moules. Good night dear boy. OSCAR goes into the Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ill assorted group. ROBBIE, OSCAR, BOSIE and his lates conquest. OSCAR is blotchy and covered with grease.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: How long are you here, Robbie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I am joining my mother in Menton on Tuesday. 3/11/16  67

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: More paraffin injections? How lovely. You should take Oscar. He looks like a rotten egg in aspic. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I was poisoned by a moule last week when Robbie arrived. I have had mysterious skin ever since.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, leprosy I expect.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Thank you, my dear. But let us talk of more cheerful things! Your fathers death, for example. How did it go?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Without a hitch for the most part. In and out of consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: As in life!

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: My brother Percy went to see him just before the end. Father opened his eyes and spat at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Queensbury rules until the end!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Well I, at least, have outlived my nemesis, although I am more or less starving at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Shovelling down Lobster Newberg!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: A magnificent treat. And at the moment, sadly all too rare. Bosie dear, this brings me rather neatly to an awkward point...

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Oscar! Do not ask me for money! I have absolutely none to spare. 3/11/16  68

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: But dear boy, you have just inherited twenty thousand pounds, have you not? Surely you do not wish to see me on the street?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: As you are behaving like an old prostitute, Oscar, perhaps the street is where you belong. OSCAR shrugs his shoulders and keeps eating.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: For Gods sake, Bosie...

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: This has nothing to do with you, Robbie. Keep out of it! Garcon!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately it has. Since Oscar threw in his lot with you at Naples, he been cut adrift by everyone. Constance has died. His sons have been taken away from him. His so called friends have deserted him. And now you, who owe him everything, turn your back.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: (screaming) I am sick and tired of being blamed for the self inflicted wounds of a gluttonous snob. I am not my lovers keeper. If he wants to eat he should work! Oscar what have you written recently? A WAITER wheels a trolley towards the table.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Ah. The Pudding trolley. (to the YOUNG MAN) I see your little eyes light up. What shall we have? Robbie, dear, you'll burst a hemorrhoid. It was only a passing thought...

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Like all your work.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You disgust me, Bosie. 3/11/16  120 121 69

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Do you suppose I care. I asked you a question Oscar. Does the flame still burn? No, it doesn’t, does it. So I am supposed to keep you in luxury while you stumble about the boulevard begging for drinks. Christ! Some of us have to work. BOSIE throws cash on to the table and storms out dragging BOY with him. With difficulty ROBBIE helps OSCAR get up f the table. INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. BEDROOM. DAY. 120 In the same movement, ROBBIE is now helping OSCAR into be the image of the restaurant recedes around them. DR. TUCKER, a SURGEON and A NURSE materialise. They are preparing for an operation. OSCAR is agitated.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Have you told Bosie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I haven’t seen him since the terrible lunch.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You must. If anything happens...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It wont. The NURSE begins to cover OSCAR in linen so that only his face and ear are visible. DR. TUCKER gives OSCAR an injection.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Is it really necessary, Dr. Tucker? I feel perfectly well, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TUCKER
dialogues.text: We shall be as quick as we can. INT. STAIRS HOTEL D’ALSACE. DAY. 121 M. DUPOIRIER comes up the stairs with towels and a jug of water. A muffled scream from inside the room. 3/11/16  122 123 70 INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. BEDROOM. DAY. 122 A medieval scene. THE SURGEON is cutting inside OSCAR’S ear. There is blood everywhere. OSCAR has come round and has crammed his clenched fists i his mouth to stop himself from crying out. THE NURSE smothers his face with a towel drenched in chloral. OSCAR'S eyes bulge and then close. INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. BEDROOM. DUSK. 123 OSCAR, trussed up in bandages, sleeps. ROBBIE, MAURICE, D TUCKER watch and whisper. He wakes. The room seems tiny. faces pressing in. OSCAR tries to focus.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Is that you Maurice? Come here immediately and ravish me!

dialogues.speaker: DR. TUCKER
dialogues.text: (stiffly) No, it is I. Dr Tucker. How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Medium, dear, rather medium. DR TUCKER puts a thermometer in OSCAR’S mouth. The door opens and REGGIE comes in wearing an overcoat, carrying a travelling bag.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Nurse Turner reporting for duty. Everyone is momentarily lifted. ROBBIE and REGGIE hug. DR TUCKER claps REGGIE on the back, and OSCAR’S eyes bulge w pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Thank God you're here.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: How is the patient?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TUCKER
dialogues.text: If he would only refrain from drinking... He removes the thermometer from OSCAR’S mouth. Looks at i Says nothing 3/11/16  71

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Darling Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TUCKER
dialogues.text: We should have him up and about in a couple of days. Do try to knock some sense in to him, Mr Turner, while you are here. Neither Mr Ross nor I seem to have any influence.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (to ROBBIE) When are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: My train is at half past nine.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Are you meeting your mother at the station?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, she’s already in Menton.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Reggie. Dr. Tucker. Would you excuse us for a moment. EVERYONE is surprised. ROBBIE and REGGIE exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: But Oscar, I’ve just arrived.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Reggie, please!

dialogues.speaker: DR. TUCKER
dialogues.text: Of course. They leave.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: What is it Oscar? OSCAR tries to speak but can’t. Finally he bursts into te

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Oh, Robbie. I shall never see you again.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Of course we shall see each other again Oscar. What are you talking about? 3/11/16  72

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Robbie, don’t go. Stay a little longer. Surely your mother can spare you...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar, you know she can’t. I’m already a week late. OSCAR continues to cry like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I shall never see you again. I know it. Hold me dearest boy. Just for a minute. I’m so afraid. Renewed sobs. ROBBIE sits on the bed and puts his arms ar OSCAR.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Don’t cry or I’ll cry too. ROBBIE rocks OSCAR back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I shall settle my mother and I be back.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Really? ROBBIE untangles himself from OSCAR who sits in his bed looking down and crying quietly. ROBBIE opens the door. REGGIE and DR. TUCKER come in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Reggie dear. Thank you so much. Let me know how it all goes, won’t you. They embrace. ROBBIE and DR. TUCKER shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look after him, Doctor, and Oscar. No drinking!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (blowing his nose) No drinking. ROBBIE kisses OSCAR on the lips, holds his hands. Goes to door. OSCAR looks like an abandoned dog, but tries to put on a brave face. 3/11/16  124 125 73

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Robbie darling, try to finda little cup in the hills above Nice where I might go to recuperate and be near you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’ll try. ROBBIE turns at the doorway, and bows slightly.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 124
dialogues.text: INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. BEDROOM. NIGHT. 125 REGGIE comes into the room and stands at the door watchin OSCAR. His eyes are closed but big tears roll from under lids.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Oscar, you old fraud. You look perfectly well.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I know. Can you believe it? One poisonous moule four months ago and I’ve been in and out of bed ever since. Dear boy, behind the commode you will find a bottle of champagne. Open it, and lets drink to your arrival.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: We shouldn’t really.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Of course we shouldn’t. You have crossed the water for a treasured friend. There are glasses under the bed. REGGIE opens the champagne. OSCAR clutches at his stomach groans as he tries to sit up.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Poor darling! But I hear you are doing a new play.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (uneasy) Yes, in a way. Robbie has left me some divine note books in which to scribble beautiful thoughts, but unfortunately I haven’t had any this year. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will tell you a terrible secret - don’t tell Robbie, please Reggie, there’s a dear. REGGIE pours champagne. OSCAR leans towards him and whisp

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have sold the play to three different individuals, and I haven't written a single word. Rather clever, don’t you think? There is nothing like an Irish beggar, once he gets into his stride.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: But what will you do when the time comes to deliver it?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Die! I am paralysed by dark thoughts. Sometimes I wonder. Is it a moule? It could be something else. Oh God!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What? OSCAR is overwhelmed, and puts his hand on his ear.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Why did Constance die? Why have I become so mad? Reggie, my brain has crashed and shattered. Is this... OSCAR is trembling. REGGIE takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What, Oscar? From OSCAR'S point of view the room is suddenly enormous. CONSTANCE appears in the distance. She walks towards the singing. She is young and beautiful and regards OSCAR lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: (whisper) Syphilis. She disappears and the room contracts. OSCAR is rigid wit fear. REGGIE watches, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Do you see the hell in which I live? Robbie wants me to write a play and I am wrestling with my soul, Reggie. I cannot write a play. 3/11/16  75

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: (kind but firm) Of course you can. You must! Now come on, Oscar. Pull yourself together. The doctor says in a few days we may take you out for a drive. You see? We’re going to have a lovely time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR, REGGIE and MAURICE drive through the park. Autumn leaves fall. The sky is white and blustery.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: What does it profit a man to gain the whole world and lose his own soul?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What? Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I was driving through the park, one Sunday, years ago, and close by Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby looking people listening to some vulgar street preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a macintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, anda wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips. It was really very good in its way. The THREE MEN laugh. OSCAR is proud of his memory.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s marvellous Oscar. Do you remember everything you’ve written?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Isn't it extraordinary. I can’t think what happened last week. One’s whole life is a blur. All that remains, clear, black and white, carved in stone, are the words. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Words written on pages under long forgotten moons. Shall we stop off for a drink on the way back?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: You know what Dr. Tucker said.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Dr. Tucker is a quack! That is the secret of his success. Come on, Reggie. I’m feeling so much better. Just not being cooped up in that terrible room is an elixir!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I couldn't agree with you more. But just one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REGGIE and MAURICE help OSCAR into the bar. A WAITER comes to the table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Ahh, M Melmoth! We’ve been worried about you

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Absinthe, Henri. Three.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Oscar!

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Fuck off, Reggie. One last drink before I die! A COUPLE raise their glasses to OSCAR. This is his local everyone is happy to see him back.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the WAITER) Have you seen the boys?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: They were here yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: You are not dying, Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Oh yes I am dear boy. It is November. I shall not outlive the century. The English would never permit it. 3/11/16  129 77 THE COUPLE have appeared and sit down. OSCAR makes introductions as drinks arrive and more are ordered. A MA enters the bar and greets OSCAR loudly. OSCAR waves grand back. CcuT TO Later, through the window of the bar, the last impromptu party is getting out of control. OSCAR is surrounded, hol forth for the last time. More drinks arrive. REGGIE, deep conversation with MAURICE, is unconcerned. INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. BEDROOM. NIGHT. 129 REGGIE and MAURICE undress a drunken OSCAR. A good deal o laughter. Finally OSCAR is tucked up in bed and sneezes loudly followed by a fart. More hilarity. REGGIE and MAUR tidy up and flirt. There is a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Who could it be at this hour? MAURICE opens the door. JEAN and LEON come into the room. They each have a bunch of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to himself) Christ! Are we to be spared nothing?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Boys! What a marvellous surprise. Sit down and have a glass of champagne. OSCAR pats the side of his bed, and the TWO BROTHERS ging sit down. Introductions are made.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how is life on the boulevard? All well in the underworld?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We heard that you’re sick.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Are you dying?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Because if you are, you have to finish the story. You still owe us ten francs, you know! 3/11/16  78

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You see, Reggie, more creditors to add to our list. I am dying beyond my means! Dear boys, you shall have the story, we shall have champagne, cocaine, and perhaps one last mauve moment for me.... Everyone groans.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a joke! Now sit down everyone and we'll begin. Where was

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: The two emeralds.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: The two emeralds. Let me see. ‘It is winter’ said the swallow. ‘In Egypt the sun is warm. My companions are building a nest in the Temple of Baalbec and pink and white doves are watching them and cooing softly to each other. Dear Prince, I must leave you, but I will never forget you and next spring I shall bring you back two beautiful jewels in place of those you have given away. Turn down the gaslight would you Reggie? In the light from the fire the group settles down. REGGIE sits on a small sofa next to MAURICE, and the TWO BROTHER the end of the bed. LEON begins to cough. There is blood. REGGIE, horrified, covers his mouth with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘In the square below,’ said the Happy Prince,’ there stands a little match boy. His matches have fallen in the gutter, and they are all spoiled. His sisters will beat him if he does not bring home some money, and he is crying. He has no shoes or stockings and his little head is bare. Pluck out my emerald eyes and give them to him, and his sisters will not beat him. Everyone listens. Eyes glitter in the firelight. REGGIE’S hand is stroking MAURICE’S leg Later REGGIE is asleep, his head on MAURICE’S shoulder. T others are nodding off. Only LEON listens intently. 3/11/16  79

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then the swallow came back to the Prince. ‘You are blind now,’ he said, ‘ so I will stay with you always.‘ Then the snow came, and after the snow came the frost. At last the swallow knew that he was going to die.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK. INT. NURSERY. NIGHT. 1889 130
dialogues.text: A different bed and different people. OSCAR’S TWO CHILDRE listen enraptured as a younger OSCAR reads.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: He had just enough strength to fly up to the Prince’s shoulder once more. ‘Goodbye dear Prince!’ He murmured. ‘I am glad you are going to Egypt little swallow.’ Said the Prince. 131 INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE BEDROOM. NIGHT. 1900. 131 OSCAR gasps, lost suddenly in memory.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: It is not to Egypt I am going. It is to the house of death. Death is the brother of sleep, is he not?’ And he kissed the Happy Prince on the lips and fell down dead at his feet. Silence. OSCAR looks around.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The disciples sleep. The end is nigh. OSCAR sneezes extravagantly. The sound of distant applause. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR and his TWO SONS watch a performance of ‘The Import Of Being Earnest’ from a box.

dialogues.speaker: DR CHASUBLE
dialogues.text: Was the cause of death mentioned?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A severe chill, it seems. 3/11/16  80

dialogues.speaker: MISS PRISM
dialogues.text: As a man sows, so shall he reap.

dialogues.speaker: DR CHASUBLE
dialogues.text: Charity, dear Miss Prism, charity! None of us is perfect. I myself am particularly susceptible to draughts. Will the internment take place here?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No. He seems to have expressed a desire to be buried in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: DR CHASUBLE
dialogues.text: In Paris! I fear that hardly points to any very serious state of mind at the end. THE AUDIENCE explode with laughter. THE BOYS look at their father with pride.

dialogues.speaker: CYRIL
dialogues.text: (leaning over and whispering) Come home soon father.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Tommorrow. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED. 133
dialogues.text: 134 INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE BEDROOM. DAY. 1900. 134 OSCAR waves goodbye. The TWO BOYS shimmer in the distance REGGIE watches concerned.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: And tomorrow and tomorrow! OSCAR eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Reggie. The boys!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Which ones? Maurice? Bosie?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Awfully sorry. So many broken hearts. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They will have to live with it. For ever. World without end. 81 THE BOYS fade away. The room contracts. OSCAR has a massi stroke. He looks wildly at REGGIE, mistakes him for a wai and gestures feebly.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Garcon, encore du champagne! INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE. CORRIDOR. NIGHT. ROBBIE and REGGIE are outside OSCAR’S room.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank God you’ve come back. Yesterday she decided I was a waiter.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: And today?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: God knows. He hasn’t spoken. And now the Doctor says he can’t last more than forty eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Have you called a Priest?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh! Should I have?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, I will then. We must. They go in to OSCAR’S room. INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE BEDROOM. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar? Oscar! No response. ROBBIE takes OSCAR’S hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? A small squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oscar, would you like me to fetch a Priest? OSCAR looks into ROBBIE’S eyes. A faint smile. He head and squeezes ROBBIE’S hand. 135 136 nods his 3/11/16  137 82 ROBBIE gets up to leave but OSCAR holds on to him, lookin intently into his eyes. ROBBIE looks around helplessly. REGGIE shrugs, but M. DUPOIRIER produces a rosary from hi waistcoat and offers it to ROBBIE, who presses it into OSCAR'S hands. OSCAR’S eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: DUPOIRIER
dialogues.text: You could try the Passionist fathers on the Rue du Bac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE and a small Irish Priest, FR. DUNNE are jolting ba towards the Hotel d’Alsace.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I must tell you, father, the dying man has been quite a well known literary figure.

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: It’s all one and the same thing to Our Lord. He has no time to read, Mr. Ross, with all of us sinners clogging up the road to hell. But who might your friend be who has come home so late and yet so thirsty for the sacred blood of Christ? A moments silence. ROBBIE takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar Wilde. FR. DUNNE’S eyeballs nearly pop out.

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! (flustered) Has Mr Wilde expressed a desire for extreme unction?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Most certainly. While he could still speak.

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: Has he been received? Is he not a protestant?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: He was meant to be a Catholic. ROBBIE breaks down. 3/11/16  83

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: Oh, my son, don’t worry. I’m sure we can sort something out. I have everything we might need with me, unless of course exorcism is called for. FR. DUNNE laughs. ROBBIE dries his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just my little joke. I must say I am quite excited. I once sat, in the gallery of course, through a performance of The Ideal Husband. Now there’s a play, although I gather Mr Wilde was not much of one himself. Still, God moves in mysterious ways, his wonders to perform. 138 INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE BEDROOM. NIGHT. 138 OSCAR lies still clutching the rosary with half opened eyes. REGGIE sits by the bed. DUPOIRIER opens the door. DR TUCKER listens to OSCAR’S pulse.

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: Ah! We're in time. Good evening M Dupoirier. We missed you on Sunday. ROBBIE goes straight to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oscar, can you hear me! This is Fr. Dunne. Reggie move! REGGIE moves into the shadows. ROBBIE sits by the bed and takes OSCAR’S hands.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (almost shouting) Oscar. Fr. Dunne is willing to receive you into the church and give you absolution but you need to sit up and pay attention....

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: Now, now Mr. Ross, between the stirrup and the ground there is always time for an act of contrition. There’s no need to hurry. Good evening Mr. Wilde. I am Father Cuthbert Dunne. Now. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am going to say some very simple things to you but I need to know that you have understood. A small sign is all that I shall need. OSCAR raises his hand slightly.

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s right. Let us all kneel. ROBBIE, DR. TUCKER, FR. DUNNE and DUPOIRIER kneel by the bed and cross themselves. REGGIE uncertainly follows suit OSCAR regards the faces around the bed and begins to pani He is somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: FR DUNNE
dialogues.text: In the name of the father and the son and the holy ghost. Amen. Father, look with pity on your servant Oscar. Absolve him of all his sins. Mr Wilde. Examine your conscience. Close on OSCAR. FR DUNNE (CONT’D) There are no secrets between man and God. Talk to him. Where did you lose sight of our Blessed Lord?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (barely a whisper) Clapham Junction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR in prison uniform, handcuffed to a guard sits on a bench waiting for a train. He is surrounded by a jeering crowd. FR. DUNNE V.O. Jesus Christ was nailed to the cross at Golgotha so that your sins may be forgiven. On the third day he rose again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR convulses. ROBBIE and REGGIE hold him down.

dialogues.speaker: FR DUNNE
dialogues.text: 3/11/16  141 142 85 I baptise you, in the name of the father and of the son and of the holy ghost. Amen. He raises his arm to sprinkle holy water on OSCAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BURLY MAN spits on OSCAR’S face in slow motion. The CRO laugh and others follow suit. INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE BEDROOM. NIGHT. 142 FR DUNNE stands up and anoints OSCAR. OSCAR'S face is covered in tears.

dialogues.speaker: FR DUNNE
dialogues.text: Though I walk in the valley of death, I raise mine eyes to the hills whence cometh my delight. OSCAR looks up into FR DUNNE’S eyes. OSCAR'S VISION OF JESUS. JESUS, bleeding, crowned with thorns, surrounded by radiance, takes OSCAR’S face in his hands and kisses his forehead, then both his wrists. OSCAR reaches out towards him but he’s gone. In his place FR DUNNE makes a final sign of the cross. The extreme unction is completed. OSCAR is more or less brain dead. Everyone stands.

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: There now. Wasn't that beautiful. I’ll be away now. If you should need me again, our friend Monsieur Dupoirier knows where to find me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: We're so grateful...

dialogues.speaker: FR. DUNNE
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s been a privilege to meet such a distinguished author. I‘1l find my own way down. FR DUNNE leaves. DUPOIRIER follows. REGGIE opens the curtains. It is dawn outside. A cold cle light. 3/11/16  143 144 145 146 86

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s going to be a beautiful day. ROBBIE sits down beside the bed, and puts his head in his hands. In the silence a deep uneven rattle, like the clanking of treadmill, comes from OSCAR’S open mouth. The TWO MEN loo up. The deathbed vigil begins. ROBBIE and REGGIE sit by the bed patiently watching. The only sound is OSCAR’S rattling breath.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK. INT READING GAOL. TREADMILL. DAY. 143
dialogues.text: OSCAR clambers on the big wheel. 1NT. HOTEL D’ALSACE BEDROOM. MORNING. 144 ROBBIE is still by the bed. REGGIE is at the window. DUPOIRIER brings a tray of food. LATER. The death rattle continues. The food is untouched but the wine has been opened. REGGIE is holding a glass.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God, how much longer?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK. INT READING GAOL. TREADMILL. DAY. 145
dialogues.text: OSCAR slips off the treadmill and bounces towards the ground but pulls himself back up and continues. INT. HOTEL D’ALSACE BEDROOM. DAY. 146 MAURICE GILBERT is sitting by OSCAR holding his hand. DR. TUCKER stands at the end of the bed. REGGIE and ROBBIE ar sitting by the window smoking and looking down into the street where life goes on in silence. Suddenly the death rattle stops. They stand and move towards the bed. OSCAR'S head lolls to one side. His eyes open suddenly fixating for ever on the framed photograph of QUEEN VICTORIA, which has followed him through exile. OSCAR'S VISION OF PARADISE. 3/11/16  147 87

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA, THE PRINCE OF WALES. PRINCESS ALEXANDRA,
dialogues.text: all THE PRINCESSES, THEIR HUSBANDS, THE COUSINS, THE GRANDCHILDREN, and THE COURT are sitting in OSCAR’S room listening enraptured.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: So they pulled down the statue of the Happy Prince. ‘As he is no longer beautiful he is no longer useful’ said the art professor at the university. Then they melted the statue in a furnace. We float from the bed, through QUEEN VICTORIA, and the ro of STIFF COURTIERS, through a door and outside into daylight. OSCAR V.O. What a strange thing’ said the overseer of the workmen at the foundry. ‘This broken lead heart will not melt. We must throw it away. So they threw it on a dust heap where the dead swallow was also lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Coffin slides out of a hearse. It is carried through a shabby Cemetery and placed in an open grave. ROBBIE and BOSIE, REGGIE, JEAN, LEON, MAURICE and Mr DUPOIRIER stand by the grave. FR DUNNE incants the committal litany. BOSIE is sobbing hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: For Christ’s sake, Bosie, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: You can’t understand, Robbie. But how could you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Understand what?

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: The sort of love that Oscar and I shared.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You've never shared anything with anybody. You’re too fucking selfish. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your so called love killed him. Where were you when he was dying?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Bobbie!

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: Here we go. You have never faced the fact that Oscar loved me and not you. Because he didn’t. Did he? However hard you tried. And how you tried! ROBBIE loses control and smacks BOSIE hard across the fac nearly knocking him over. ROBBIE turns and walks away. REGGIE and MAURICE manage to stop BOSIE from falling into the grave. ROBBIE leaves the cemetery. In the background BOSIE screams.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You second rate dwarf. Do you know what Oscar thought about you?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Stop it, Bosie!

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE
dialogues.text: He thought you were a useful bore. When history looks back, it won't be at you. It will be at him and ME. You'll just be a footnote you dreary little cunt. Close on ROBBIE. Noise of a foghorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE is on board looking back towards France as the boa pulls out of the fog bound harbour and disappears into th green haze. OSCAR V.O. ‘Bring me the two most precious things in the city’ said God to one of his angels and the angel brought him the leaden heart and the dead bird.’ You have rightly chosen’ said God ‘ for in my garden of paradise this little bird shall sing for ever more and in my city of gold the Happy Prince shall praise me. 3/11/16  149 89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN blows out a candle by the bed of TWO SLEEPING CHILDREN. He regards them lovingly, then quietly leaves t room, closing the door behind him.
